channel.title: NPR Programs: All Things Considered
channel.description: All Things Considered hosts Ailsa Chang, Mary Louise Kelly, Juana Summers and Scott Detrow present the program's trademark mix of news, interviews, commentaries, reviews, and offbeat features 7 days a week.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: House Oversight Committee member talks about emails that appear to tie Epstein to Trump
item.description: NPR's Scott Detrow speaks with Rep. Robert Garcia, ranking Democratic member of the House Oversight Committee, about newly-public emails that appear to tie Jeffrey Epstein to President Trump.
item.content:encoded: NPR's Scott Detrow speaks with Rep. Robert Garcia, ranking Democratic member of the House Oversight Committee, about newly-public emails that appear to tie Jeffrey Epstein to President Trump.
item.dc:creator: Alejandra Marquez Janse

item.title: How ending the Digital Equity Act has disrupted programs to help people get online
item.description: President Trump ended the Digital Equity Act that funded equipment and services for communities and organizations that are underserved by high-speed Internet. We look at who's affected and how.
item.content:encoded: President Trump ended the Digital Equity Act that funded equipment and services for communities and organizations that are underserved by high-speed Internet. We look at who's affected and how.
item.dc:creator: Shelly Brisbin

item.title: What California's lower cannabis tax will mean for the programs that get the revenue
item.description: California just lowered its cannabis tax from 19% to 15%, to keep people buying on the legal market. But youth groups and drug-prevention programs that get much of that tax revenue are concerned.
item.content:encoded: California just lowered its cannabis tax from 19% to 15%, to keep people buying on the legal market. But youth groups and drug-prevention programs that get much of that tax revenue are concerned.
item.dc:creator: April Dembosky

item.title: New Epstein files show ties to, and ire toward, Trump
item.description: As the House Oversight Committee releases new documents related to the case of convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein, the ties Epstein had to Trump are once again in the spotlight.
item.content:encoded: As the House Oversight Committee releases new documents related to the case of convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein, the ties Epstein had to Trump are once again in the spotlight.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Fowler

item.title: Here's an idea: What if Japan's matcha were protected like France's champagne?
item.description: NPR's Ailsa Chang talks with David Fickling, opinion writer at Bloomberg, about his idea for Japan: Treat matcha, the super popular drink, like champagne, and protect its heritage.
item.content:encoded: NPR's Ailsa Chang talks with David Fickling, opinion writer at Bloomberg, about his idea for Japan: Treat matcha, the super popular drink, like champagne, and protect its heritage.
item.dc:creator: Ailsa Chang

item.title: For students who rely on SNAP, school food pantries offer some relief
item.description: A school in Pittsburgh has set up a food pantry for students and their families whose SNAP benefits have been cut or delayed because of the government shutdown.
item.content:encoded: A school in Pittsburgh has set up a food pantry for students and their families whose SNAP benefits have been cut or delayed because of the government shutdown.
item.dc:creator: Jillian Forstadt

item.title: PBS documentary looks at 25 years of the challenges of surviving in space on the ISS
item.description: This year is the 25th anniversary of humans inhabiting the International Space Station. A new PBS documentary looks at how the ISS was built and the challenges of surviving in outer space.
item.content:encoded: This year is the 25th anniversary of humans inhabiting the International Space Station. A new PBS documentary looks at how the ISS was built and the challenges of surviving in outer space.
item.dc:creator: Jeanette Woods

item.title: Pro tips for photographing the northern lights
item.description: St. Louis Public Radio's visuals editor Brian Munoz shares how best to capture the Northern Lights on camera.
item.content:encoded: St. Louis Public Radio's visuals editor Brian Munoz shares how best to capture the Northern Lights on camera.
item.dc:creator: Brian Munoz

item.title: House votes to end the longest shutdown in history
item.description: The House has voted on a bill to end the government shutdown after 43 days. President Trump is expected to sign the bill on Wednesday night, paving the way for many federal workers to return to work.
item.content:encoded: The House has voted on a bill to end the government shutdown after 43 days. President Trump is expected to sign the bill on Wednesday night, paving the way for many federal workers to return to work.
item.dc:creator: Deirdre Walsh

item.title: The novel 'Some Bright Nowhere' dwells on the uncertain time between life and death
item.description: NPR's Mary Louise Kelly talks with the author Ann Packer about her new novel, Some Bright Nowhere.
item.content:encoded: NPR's Mary Louise Kelly talks with the author Ann Packer about her new novel, Some Bright Nowhere.
item.dc:creator: Mary Louise Kelly
